source.name: Gapminder
source.additionalInfo: Gapminder dataset. Available online at http://www.gapminder.org/.

187.name: Real GDP at chained PPPs in 2011 US$ (Penn World Table 9.0 (2016))
187.datasetName: Real GDP at chained PPPs in 2011 US$ - Penn World Table 9.0 (2016)

source.name: Penn World Table 9.0 (2016)
source.additionalInfo:
Expenditure-side real GDP at chained PPPs, to compare relative living standards across countries and over time. It is the ratio of the 'rgdpe' and 'pop' series.

More detailed information about this dataset can be found in the source documentation at: http://www.rug.nl/research/ggdc/data/pwt/v90/what_is_new_in_pwt90.pdf

3636.name: Hidden Hunger Index in pre-school children (Muthayya et al. (2013))
3636.description: The HHI-PD score ranged between the best and worst possible scores of 0 and 100, respectively.
3636.datasetName: Hidden Hunger Index in pre-school children - Muthayya et al. (2013)
3636.s_name: Hidden Hunger Index in pre-school children - Muthayya et al. (2013)

source.name: Hidden Hunger Index in pre-school children - Muthayya et al. (2013)
source.dataPublishedBy: Muthayya, S., Rah, J. H., Sugimoto, J. D., Roos, F. F., Kraemer, K., & Black, R. E. (2013). The global hidden hunger indices and maps: an advocacy tool for action. PLoS One, 8(6).
source.additionalInfo:
The authors note: "Hidden Hunger Index (HHI-PD) for preschool-age children is calculated as the average of three deficiency prevalence estimates: preschool children affected by stunting, anemia due to iron deficiency, and vitamin-A deficiency. The three components were equally weighted (HHI-PD score = [stunting (%) + anemia (%) + low serum retinol (%)]/3).

The HHI-PD score ranged between the best and worst possible scores of 0 and 100, respectively. Applying arbitrary cut-offs, HHI-PD scores between 0 and 19.9 were considered mild, 20-34.9 as moderate, 35-44.9 as severe, and 45-100 as alarmingly high. Highly developed countries with a 2007 Human Development Index (HDI) score above 0.9 (n=41) were assumed to have a low prevalence of micronutrient deficiencies, and were therefore excluded from this analysis.

Data on micronutrient deficiencies used in this index relate to national-level analysis and surveys over the period 1999-2009.
